blocks.name: diff.cmdat.s
diff.cmdat.c
diff.cmdat.w
df-mdet
blocks.content: Determinant of a square matrix. This definition is based on Leibniz' Formula (see ~ mdetleib ). The properties of the axiomatic definition of a determinant according to [Weierstrass] p. 272 are derived from this definition as theorems: "The determinant function is the unique multilinear, alternating and normalized function from the algebra of square matrices of the same dimension over a commutative ring to this ring". The functionality is shown by ~ mdetf . Multilineary means "linear for each row" - the additivity is shown by ~ mdetrlin , the homogeneity by ~ mdetrsca . Furthermore, it is shown that the determinant function is alternating (see ~ mdetralt ) and normalized (see ~ mdet1 ). Finally, the uniqueness is shown by ~ mdetuni . As a consequence, the "determinant of a square matrix" is the function value of the determinant function for this square matrix, see ~ mdetleib . (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 9-Sep-2015.) (Revised by SO, 10-Jul-2018.)

  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s2, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s4)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s3, s4)
  -| diffss(s1, s4)
}

axiom df-mdet(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4) {
  ‚ä¢ maDet =(s0 ‚àà ùïå, s1 ‚àà ùïå ‚Ü¶(s2 ‚àà(Base `(s0[Mat]s1))‚Ü¶(s1[gsum](s3 ‚àà(Base `(SymGrp ` s0))‚Ü¶((((ZRHom ` s1)‚àò(pmSgn ` s0))` s3)[(√ó ` s1)]((mulGrp ` s1)[gsum](s4 ‚àà s0 ‚Ü¶((s3 ` s4)[s2]s4))))))))
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s2, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s2, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s1)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s3, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s4)
}

  ‚ä¢ c0 =(s0 ‚àà c1 ‚Ü¶(c2[gsum](s1 ‚àà c3 ‚Ü¶(((c4 ‚àò c5)` s1)[c6](c7[gsum](s2 ‚àà c8 ‚Ü¶((s1 ` s2)[s0]s2)))))))
  ‚ä£ c0 =(c8[maDet]c2)
  ‚ä£ c9 =(c8[Mat]c2)
  ‚ä£ c1 =(Base ` c9)
  ‚ä£ c3 =(Base `(SymGrp ` c8))
  ‚ä£ c4 =(ZRHom ` c2)
  ‚ä£ c5 =(pmSgn ` c8)
  ‚ä£ c6 =(√ó ` c2)

  ‚ä£ d(s0, s1)

} = {
  a1ii(c0 =(s0 ‚àà c1 ‚Ü¶(c2[gsum](s1 ‚àà c3 ‚Ü¶(((c4 ‚àò c5)` s1)[c6](c7[gsum](s2 ‚àà c8 ‚Ü¶((s1 ` s2)[s0]s2))))))), d(s0, c3))

blocks.name: mdetleib
blocks.content: Full substitution of our determinant definition (also known as Leibniz' Formula, expanding by columns). Proposition 4.6 in [Lang] p. 514. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 3-Oct-2015.) (Revised by SO, 9-Jul-2018.)
blocks.origin:
thm mdetleib(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, class c6, class c7, class c8, class c9, class c10) {
  |- wi(wcel(c0, c1), wceq(cfv(c2, c0), co(c3, cgsu, cmpt(s0, c4, co(cfv(ccom(c5, c6), cv(s0)), c7, co(c8, cgsu, cmpt(s1, c9, co(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c0, cv(s1)))))))))
  -| wceq(c2, co(c9, cmdat, c3))
  -| wceq(c10, co(c9, cmat, c3))
  -| wceq(c1, cfv(cbs, c10))

  -| diffsc(s1, c3)
  -| diffsc(s1, c9)
} = {
  fvmpt(hs0, c0, c1, c2, co(c3, cgsu, cmpt(s0, c4, co(cfv(ccom(c5, c6), cv(s0)), c7, co(c8, cgsu, cmpt(s1, c9, co(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c0, cv(s1))))))), co(c3, cgsu, cmpt(s0, c4, co(cfv(ccom(c5, c6), cv(s0)), c7, co(c8, cgsu, cmpt(s1, c9, co(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cv(hs0), cv(s1))))))))
  oveq2d(c3, cgsu, cmpt(s0, c4, co(cfv(ccom(c5, c6), cv(s0)), c7, co(c8, cgsu, cmpt(s1, c9, co(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cv(hs0), cv(s1)))))), cmpt(s0, c4, co(cfv(ccom(c5, c6), cv(s0)), c7, co(c8, cgsu, cmpt(s1, c9, co(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c0, cv(s1)))))), wceq(cv(hs0), c0))
  mpteq2dv(s0, c4, co(cfv(ccom(c5, c6), cv(s0)), c7, co(c8, cgsu, cmpt(s1, c9, co(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cv(hs0), cv(s1))))), co(cfv(ccom(c5, c6), cv(s0)), c7, co(c8, cgsu, cmpt(s1, c9, co(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c0, cv(s1))))), wceq(cv(hs0), c0))
  oveq2d(cfv(ccom(c5, c6), cv(s0)), c7, co(c8, cgsu, cmpt(s1, c9, co(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cv(hs0), cv(s1)))), co(c8, cgsu, cmpt(s1, c9, co(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c0, cv(s1)))), wceq(cv(hs0), c0))
  oveq2d(c8, cgsu, cmpt(s1, c9, co(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), cv(hs0), cv(s1))), cmpt(s1, c9, co(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c0, cv(s1))), wceq(cv(hs0), c0))

  ovex(c3, cgsu, cmpt(s0, c4, co(cfv(ccom(c5, c6), cv(s0)), c7, co(c8, cgsu, cmpt(s1, c9, co(cfv(cv(s0), cv(s1)), c0, cv(s1)))))))
  diff.hs0.c(c0)

  diff.wceq.s(s0, cv(hs0), c0)

  ‚ä¢ (c0 ‚àà c1 ‚Üí(c2 ` c0)=(c3[gsum](s0 ‚àà c4 ‚Ü¶(((c5 ‚àò c6)` s0)[c7](c8[gsum](s1 ‚àà c9 ‚Ü¶((s0 ` s1)[c0]s1)))))))
  ‚ä£ c2 =(c9[maDet]c3)

  fvmpt(hs0, c0, c1, c2, (c3[gsum](s0 ‚àà c4 ‚Ü¶(((c5 ‚àò c6)` s0)[c7](c8[gsum](s1 ‚àà c9 ‚Ü¶((s0 ` s1)[c0]s1)))))), (c3[gsum](s0 ‚àà c4 ‚Ü¶(((c5 ‚àò c6)` s0)[c7](c8[gsum](s1 ‚àà c9 ‚Ü¶((s0 ` s1)[hs0]s1)))))))
  oveq2d(c3, cgsu, (s0 ‚àà c4 ‚Ü¶(((c5 ‚àò c6)` s0)[c7](c8[gsum](s1 ‚àà c9 ‚Ü¶((s0 ` s1)[hs0]s1))))), (s0 ‚àà c4 ‚Ü¶(((c5 ‚àò c6)` s0)[c7](c8[gsum](s1 ‚àà c9 ‚Ü¶((s0 ` s1)[c0]s1))))), hs0 = c0)

  oveq2d(c8, cgsu, (s1 ‚àà c9 ‚Ü¶((s0 ` s1)[hs0]s1)), (s1 ‚àà c9 ‚Ü¶((s0 ` s1)[c0]s1)), hs0 = c0)

blocks.name: mdet0pr
blocks.content: The determinant for 0-dimensional matrices is a singleton containing an ordered pair with the singleton containing the empty set as first component, and the singleton containing the 1 element of the underlying ring as second component. (Contributed by AV, 28-Feb-2019.)

blocks.name: mdet0f1o
blocks.content: The determinant for 0-dimensional matrices is a one-to-one function from the singleton containing the empty set onto the singleton containing the 1 element of the underlying ring.function x is . (Contributed by AV, 28-Feb-2019.)

blocks.name: mdet0fv0
blocks.content: The determinant of a 0-dimensional matrix is the 1 element of the underlying ring . (Contributed by AV, 28-Feb-2019.)

blocks.name: mdetf
blocks.content: Functionality of the determinant, see also definition in [Lang] p. 513. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 9-Jul-2018.) (Proof shortened by AV, 23-Jul-2019.)

blocks.name: mdetcl

blocks.name: m1detdiag
blocks.content: The determinant of a 1-dimensional matrix equals its (single) entry. (Contributed by AV, 6-Aug-2019.)

blocks.name: mdetdiag
blocks.content: The determinant of a diagonal matrix is the product of the entries in the diagonal. (Contributed by AV, 17-Aug-2019.)

blocks.name: mdetdiagid
blocks.content: The determinant of a diagonal matrix with identical entries is the power of the entry in the diagonal. (Contributed by AV, 17-Aug-2019.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: mdet1

blocks.name: mdetrlin
blocks.content: The determinant function is additive for each row: The matrices X, Y, Z are identical except for the I's row, and the I's row of the matrix X is the componentwise sum of the I's row of the matrices Y and Z. In this case the determinant of X is the sum of the determinants of Y and Z. (Contributed by SO, 9-Jul-2018.) (Proof shortened by AV, 23-Jul-2019.)

blocks.name: mdetrsca
blocks.content: The determinant function is homogeneous for each row: The matrices X and Z are identical except for the I's row, and the I's row of the matrix X is the componentwise product of the I's row of the matrix Z and the scalar Y. In this case the determinant of X is the determinant of Z multiplied by Y. (Contributed by SO, 9-Jul-2018.) (Proof shortened by AV, 23-Jul-2019.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: mdetrsca2
blocks.content: The determinant function is homogeneous for each row (matrices are given explicitly by their entries). (Contributed by SO, 16-Jul-2018.)

blocks.name: mdetr0
blocks.content: The determinant of a matrix with a row containing only 0's is 0. (Contributed by SO, 16-Jul-2018.)

blocks.name: mdetralt
blocks.content: The determinant function is alternating regarding rows: if a matrix has two identical rows, its determinant is 0. Corollary 4.9 in [Lang] p. 515. (Contributed by SO, 10-Jul-2018.) (Proof shortened by AV, 23-Jul-2018.)

blocks.name: mdetero
blocks.content: The determinant function is multilinear (additive and homogeneous for each row (matrices are given explicitly by their entries). Corollary 4.9 in [Lang] p. 515. (Contributed by SO, 16-Jul-2018.)

blocks.name: mdetuni
blocks.content: According to the definition in [Weierstrass] p. 272, the determinant function is the unique multilinear, alternating and normalized function from the algebra of square matrices of the same dimension over a commutative ring to this ring. So for any multilinear (mdetuni.li and mdetuni.sc), alternating (mdetuni.al) and normalized (mdetuni.no) function D (mdetuni.ff) from the algebra of square matrices (mdetuni.a) to their underlying commutative ring (mdetuni.cr), the function value of this function D for a matrix F (mdetuni.f) is the determinant of this matrix. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 15-Jul-2018.) (Revised by Alexander van der Vekens, 8-Feb-2019.)

blocks.name: mdetmul
blocks.content: Multiplicativity of the determinant function: the determinant of a matrix product of square matrices equals the product of their determinants. Proposition 4.15 in [Lang] p. 517. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 16-Jul-2018.)
